msDesc.head: Pelagius (Ps.-Augustine) and Ps.-Alcuin, Tracts in Middle English

msItem.rubric: Here begynneþ a tretice þat seint austyn made to a widowe of cristene religioun. fol. 1r
msItem.incipit: That y synner and þe laste and more vnwiser þan oþere. and more vnlerned þan alle fol. 1r
msItem.explicit: that whiche þinge we present mowen nor ȝeue: we absent brynge. fol. 35r
msItem.finalRubric: Here endiþ seynt austens book of cristen lijf. fol. 35r
msItem.author: Pelagius (Ps.-Augustine)
msItem.title: De vita christiana [Middle English]
msItem.note: Anon. translation of Pelagius (Ps.-Augustine), De vita christiana, pr. PL 40. 1031-46; CPL 730. English text unprinted. IMEP 1.

msItem.rubric: Here bigynneþ a sermoun of seint austen howe man is maad to þe ymage and liknesse of god his maker of nouȝt. fol. 35r
msItem.incipit: How grete is the dignite of mannes makynge fol. 35r
msItem.explicit: in þe secounde adam þat is in crist. fol. 38v
msItem.finalRubric: Here endiþ austens sermoun howe man is maad to þe ymage and liknesse of almyȝty god in trinite. Amen. fol. 38v
msItem.author: Ps.-Alcuin
msItem.title: Dicta Albini [Middle English]
msItem.note: Anon. translation of the Ps.-Alcuin, Dicta Albini (pr. PL no. 565-8, also PL 17. 1015-18, as Ambrose, CPPM 131); ed. J. Marenbon, From the Circle of Alcuin to the School of Auxerre (Cambridge, 1981), 158-61. English text unprinted. IMEP 1.

msItem.rubric: Here spekiþ seint austyn of þe xii abusiouns or mysuses. i. fol. 38v
msItem.incipit: The firste abusioun is a wise man withoute good werkis fol. 38v
msItem.explicit: wiþ outen us in tyme to comynge. fol. 59r
msItem.finalRubric: Here endiþ þe xij abusiouns or mysuses of seynt austen. fol. 59r
msItem.author: Ps.-Cyprian (Ps.-Augustine)
msItem.title: De xii abusionum gradibus [Middle English]

note.p: Anon. translation of Ps.-Cyprian (Ps.-Augustine), De xii abusionum gradibus, pr. PL 40. 1079-88; CPL 1106. English text unprinted. IMEP 2.

msItem.incipit: Ye wote wele þat wheete beynge in þe scheef is not able to be serued afore a lord at his table fol. 59v
msItem.explicit: afore oure lord in heuene wiþ hym to dwelle there with oute ende. A.M.E.N. fol. 60r
msItem.title: Life of the Spirit

note.p: Anon., pr. from this manuscript [by C. Kirchberger, with modernized spelling] Life of the Spirit, vi (1951- 2), 238. No other copy is known. IMEP 2. fol. 60v is blank.

msItem.rubric: Here bigynnyth a tretice. þat seynt austen maad to an eerle. caoi. fol. 61r
msItem.incipit: A my broþere. ȝif þu coueytist to wite. þouȝ. I wite not fol. 61r
msItem.explicit: þe fadyr euerlastynge and hooly goost in to worldis of worldis. Amen. fol. 126v
msItem.finalRubric: ihesus Here endiþ þe tretice þat seynt austen made to an eerl. fol. 126v
msItem.author: Ps.-Augustine
msItem.title: De salutaribus documentis [Middle English]

note.p: Anon. translation of the Ps.-Augustine De salutaribus documentis (pr. PL 40. 1047-78); ed. S. L. Fristedt, The Wycliffe Bible: Part. II (Stockholm, 1969), 1-60, from BL, MS Harley 2330 with emendations from this manuscript and CUL, MS Ii.6.55. Fristedt, p. lxxi, states that our text is complete, but in its first half it teems with omissions, errors, unwarranted corrections and aberrations, which are not due to the scribe, whose writing is beautifully neat and clear. On the gap left in the text and filled by a second scribe see Script below. IMEP 2; IPMEP, no. 41.

physDesc.p: Fore- and endleaves: fols. ir-iiv, Ir-IIv blank

support.p: Written on 126 leaves of rather stiff membrane, trimmed, preceded and followed by two modern paper flyleaves.

collation.catchwords: Catchwords (by scribe) at bottom of final versos, in a cartouche touched with red.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in one column, 113 80 mm. 21 lines, except fols. 92r, 23 lines, and 92v, 22 lines. Prickings for verticals only remain. Ruled in crayon within the verticals except that three pairs of double lines, at top, middle, and bottom, are ruled across both margins. In quires where a difference in the membrane can be detected, folding is FSOS.

handDesc.handNote: A gothic semiquadrata bookhand, by one scribe except fols. 90v/16 'þe herte' to 92v/2 'glad', inserted in a space left for the missing text: this was fitted in by another scribe by adding two extra lines to fol. 92r and one at the top of fol. 92v. Punctuation is by low point, colon, and single and double virgula. There are occasional nota marks (na.) in margin, in scribe's hand touched with red.

decoDesc.decoNote: Three-line red lombards flourished blue at beginnings of texts on fols. 1r and 61r
Otherwise initials are two-line red, unflourished. The plain initials do not always cover the guide letters that had been written by the scribe.
Some extensions of ordinary letters into lower and outer margins are decorated with the pen and sometimes touched with red.
In the margins are a few quite delicate floral decorations made with the pen and touched with red.

binding.p: Sewn on five bands between millboards covered with 18th-century calf, rebacked. Repaired by Maltby June 1962.

history.provenance: At the top of fol. 1r are the remains, after trimming, of what was probably a name in a cursive hand, perhaps medieval.
On fol. fol. 2r is Frauncis Mauestyer (or Maneskyer, etc., s. xvi) and on fol. 126v are pen-trials in three hands probably of s. xviin.
The reason for Coxe's statement that the volume was Olim Narcissi Luttrell is not apparent
history.acquisition: How the book came to All Souls is not clear. All Souls library identifications, on which see Introduction, are, on the front pastedown, vv.14.i. (deleted), M.S. 24 (figure added), L.R. 1.f.1(pencil), 105 (pencil), and bookplate no. 10.

recordHist.source: Andrew G. Watson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts of All Souls College Oxford (Oxford, 1997)
